content.description: A tricky boulder-problem start leads to thin face climbing above. The final moves surmount an exciting blocky overhang. The route is moderate 5.10 if the right arete is utilized for the middle portion (above the third bolt). A few more "tense moments" can be had by eschewing the arete and climbing straight up the thin crimpy face (5.11). This route is unusual for Spring Mountain in that it is easy to set up for a top-rope from above (without leading).
content.location: Start at left edge of small roof 20 ft. right of Jack and Jill

content.description: The last route on the cliff. This one lives up to its name if you enjoy steep rock with big holds. Start at the same place as Clean Sweep and climb straight up a system of fractures and blocks (they're solid) to a ledge. A few tricky slab moves get you to the top of the route.
Begins under the overhang below and left of the regular route and climbs past three bolts. Might want to stick clip the first bolt.
A nice way to start the day
content.location: Face climb just past small overhang

content.description: Follow ledges right of Initiation to rap hangers 25 ft. up. Good beginner or kid's route.
Crack system right of Steppin' Out. Bail out at rap hangers after 60' as upper part of crack has not been cleaned.
Definitely lives up to it's name.  Original anchors gone, move up and right at top to anchors for Eekwinocks
content.location: Located in the "eastern segment." Just left of the crack climb Eekwinocks

content.description: Left slanting hand/finger crack 8 ft. right of Epiphany. Ends on same ledge system as Epiphany. There are no anchors but it is possible to traverse right to the Epiphany anchors.
Starts on steep crimpy face 10 ft right of Eaten Alive. Stick clipping first bolt is a good idea. Route continues straight up alternating between slabs and gently overhanging faces.

Climb ledgy face left of crack in dihedral to rap hangers (5.5). Stop here or crank through a steep lieback and fist crack (5.9) to ledge with rap hangers. Variation: (Dirty Dancing, trad, 5.7) - Traverse left at the lower anchors to upper crack of Red and climb through a short steep bulge to reach the anchors for Fab Slab.
content.location: Crack in corner right of Fab Slab

content.description: Starts in shallow flared dihedral 20 ft. right of Chicken Pox. Pull through short steep bulge to sloping ledge with anchors.

The direct start takes off just to the right of Rally Race and climbs a short overhanging section with 4 bolts.  The climb continues up and left via a crack system to 1st set of anchors.  Head up and right of first anchors for the extension and 3 more bolts.  Upper section was dirty/loose but recently cleaned and new anchors installed.  Rock is fairly soft at the top of the cliff, thus the bolts. 

  An easier variation is to start on Geophysical then move left once past the overhang.
content.location: Central Segment, between Rally Race and Geophysical

climbs.name: Summertime Arete
climbs.fa: Bob Branscomb, Kristi Stouffer, Jack Kay and Linda Hall. 80's

content.description: Right side of arete 5 ft. right of Johnny Nowhere. Finish at rap hangers on ledge half-way up or keep climbing to reach another set of rap hangers after 5 more bolts "Endless Summer".

Steppin out starts with face climbing on a small buttress that aims for a crack over right. Use this crack for several feet before "stepping out" left to navigate a series of barn door inducing edges. Great, technical climbing through the crux on this one.
content.location: 10' right of Get a Grip, just left of Van Golden Brown crack.

content.description: Crack in corner right of Oot and Aboot. After 50 feet, the crack deteriorates, so step right to double cold shut anchors.
content.protection: gear, finishes on shuts at the top.

content.description: Route climbs the obvious arete at the edge of a large detached buttress.
content.location: Located in the "eastern segment" of Spring Mountain.  It is the last climb before the big chimmney

content.description: Thin steep face climbing on outside of large detached buttress. Can be finished directly (about 5.10b) via two bolts through overhang.
Dihedral above anchors for Hawaiian Slab. Creative stemming and power crimping permits a traverse left under overhang to anchors above a good ledge.
Stem up outside edge of chimney system directly above Cassidy's Crack.
Starts on slabby face right of The Diving Board, and continues up steep headwall above.
Face climb right of Lively Up Yourself. Wander left and back right, then pull through a small overhang.

Climb steep face 20 ft. right of Trix using sharp arete on right. Pull into dihedral and stem up to a good ledge with chains 45 ft. up. Stop here or scramble up and left on some easy ground to more fun climbing on an exposed slab. Climb ends at chains near the top of the cliff.
Face climb 6 ft. right of Blackout.

Clip the anchors for Wanderer and continue straight up into a dihedral with fun liebacking (5.9). Clip the rap hangers and come down from underneath the big roof or make a sketchy traverse right past two bolts to reach another crack/dihedral system. Follow a tips crack straight up (soft rock and small gear) and then move right underneath another bulge (crux) staying to the right of a wider crack. Beware of rope drag after the roof. You'll need a 60 meter rope to top-rope.
Interesting and longish route. The crux is an ackward lay-back/ stem over the left side of dog show. I know many climbers who struggle with the ackward crux, but I found it fun.
content.location: Shares a start with dog show before climbing left around a corner and finishing on the upper face.

content.description: Shares first 4 bolts with Noble Slabbage. Climb the slab staying just left of the wide crack. From the Noble Slabbage anchor ledge, step up and right onto a steep face with prominent flake. Continue up past 8 bolts to anchors near the top of the cliff.
content.location: The next three climbs all start at the head of the steep eroding slope right of Noble Slabbage. This is the one on the left.

content.description: Start in left-leaning crack in ledgy slab just right of Captain Winkie. Angle back to the right above a wide mossy section of the crack to reach a steep finger crack. Climb this crack (crux) to the anchors for Captain Winkie.
Crack 5 ft. right of Flaked Out. Exit left 60 ft. up to double cold shuts.
content.protection: Gear to 3" and chains at the top.

content.description: Climb reachy crimpy face right of Fab Slab past 3 bolts to crack. Climb crack straight up through bulge to Fab Slab anchors.
Just right of the Pod of God climb steep face to prominent flake. The flake leads many to confuse this route with "flaked out"
content.protection: Stick clip first bolt. 6 bolts to rap hangers .

content.description: Steep face immediately right of Hospital Corner.

climbs.name: Pod of God
climbs.fa: ???? tell me and I will update

content.description: This is a fun little crack route that shares an anchor with Rally Racer. I think this is a great lead for someone starting out on trad as it protects very well. The pod is a pretty fun feature and the crux seemed to be coming out of the pod. Single pitch with bolted anchors.
content.location: This is at the start of the Amphitheater to the left of Rally Racer. Rally Racer is the obvious, large detached flake.

content.description: Face climb on south corner of large detached buttress just around the corner from Phish Food.

Sustained 5.10+ climbing leads to good rest on a small ledge before an awkward dyno off a two finger pocket to a good jug by the final bolt. This route is far more interesting if you only stem off the opposite wall to the first bolt. (Shares anchors with Spring Fever)
content.location: To the right of Spring Fever inside the cave, on your left as you walk up toward Maid in the Shade

content.description: Finger crack in shallow right facing dihedral at head of 2nd talus field. Lieback up a nice flake above dihedral and then traverse right past an awkward bulge to chain anchors 50 ft. up. #3.5 friend protects the traverse.
Climbs face with small overhang 10 ft. right of Phoups. Shares chains with Phoups.

Climb steep smooth face using arete on right, pull through an overhang, move slightly left and then scamper up a blunt arete and around a big block. Shares anchors with A Few Tense Moments and is therefore also easy to set up for a top-rope from above, although you might want a directional quick-draw lower down.
content.location: Face climb 10 ft. right of A Few Tense Moments.

content.description: Climbs steep corner on right side of chimney system right of Gran Delusion.
content.protection: clip 6 bolts on the way to chains at the top.

content.description: Prominent arete 5 feet right of Chopper. Five bolts lead to rap hangers at obvious ledge (Oot). Continue past 10 more bolts to chains near the top of the cliff (Aboot).

Climb the first part of Van Golden Brown until it is possible to exit right to a thin crack about 20 ft. up. Follow the thin crack straight up (somewhat difficult to protect) to the ledge with anchors for Lorraine.
Thin crack system in face right of Puppets Without Strings. When cracks end midway up face, move right and follow bolts to anchors for Johnny Nowhere.
content.protection: 4 bolts, gear to 2", chains at top.

content.description: Slab to overhanging rounded arete. From atop the bulge, step left after the overhang. When leading, do not clip the bolt on the RIGHT after the bulge (this is a directional for top-roping). Do clip the bolt on the LEFT just above the roof, then run out (#3 cam optional here) to the next bolt.
content.protection: Take a #3 friend to supplement bolts above overhang (optional). 12 bolts to chains.

content.description: Climb straight up the middle of the slab, veering right to gain the ledge above the 4th bolt. Holds right of bolt line (below 4th bolt) are off-route.
content.location: Starts on small ledge 5 ft. right of Funny Trumpets Arete.

content.description: A short finger cranking route with a bolt protecting the crux.  The route follows a discontinuos finger crack that trends left around a small flake and straight up to a rounded layback .  Though the crux is probably 11+, placing gear off the sustained finger locks before it bump the grade.  It is far easier to place a couple pieces at the little flake and then gun for the bolt, but the finger lock section also accepts perfect stopper placements if you got the lock strength.
content.protection: medium to large stoppers, and a couple .25-.75 cams, a bolt protects the crux.
content.location: Just left of Gran Delusion, a broken crack and chimney system.

content.description: This line heads straight up the face above and right of Mountain Ears Route.
Face 4 ft. right and around corner from The Final Shred. Crack on right and arete on left are off-route for 11b rating.
Pull a strenuous overhanging block and then undercling your way up and left (sketchy feet) to the finish
content.location: Somewhat narrower crack right of Fish for the Future.

content.description: Scramble up ledges, crank over a bulge (crux) and then cruise a ledgy face with good protection to a tunnel-like exit beneath a large chockstone. Good route for beginning traditional lead climber.
content.protection: Standard rack. No fixed top anchors.
content.location: Left-facing dihedral with crack just right of Passing Lane

content.description: From the anchors for Hawaiian Slab, jam the crack on the right wall of the dihedral to below a roof. Pull through the roof using the magnificent hand crack provided. The route ends at chains 10' above the roof.

This is on of the best routes I have climbed at the forested area where the trail comes up to the cliffs. Climb a short slab to a shallow dihedral that moves you out onto the gently overhanging face.The crux for me was some powerful moves on good holds out the overhanging section. Up higher is a really fun left leaning edge.
content.location: To the right of the sphinx crack.

content.description: Climb the steep, apparently well-featured slab just past the wide dirty crack right of Nurse Ratchet. Most of those nice looking holds vanish into thin air on close approach.
Climb the crack in the corner 4 ft. right of Crack Atowa. Ends below roof at rap hangers.
Face to the right of Chicken Pox.
Climb a blunt arete with a strenuous mantle to an overhang surmounted with another difficult mantle. The slab above is equally challenging.
content.location: This is the right route at the head of the steep eroding slope.

content.description: Maid in the Shade, like the name suggests, starts deep in the shaded chimney behind Spring Fever.  Highly varied route with some chimney, face, and arete climbing.
content.location: Behind Spring Fever in the "eastern segment."  Scramble to the back of the chimney and look for the bolts leading up through a gap.

content.description: Climb the crack in the corner right of Gidrah via strenuous fist jams and surmount the obvious flake and roof on the right using the huge holds provided. Continue straight up to the top of the cliff clipping 4 bolts on the steep knobby face of the upper section of The Final Shred.
Starts at large crack just right of Plumber Boy and takes right-leaning finger crack across steep face, intersecting Spring Cling about 20' up. Finish at anchors for Spring Cling.
content.protection: Gear, 3 bolts to chains shared with Spring Cling

content.description: Fun, sustained route that follows a broken crack with lots of pockets.  One of the best bolt routes at Spring Mountain and a classic 'warm-up'.
content.location: Located about halfway down the wall, right behind the prominent pine tree in the corner.

content.description: Steep thin crack between Arthritis and Hospital Corner. Climb largely on face, protecting in crack.

A mostly vertical crack that rangers from thin fingers to fists.  Short and mostly vertical with abundant features on the face as well.  Crux is low.  A short but fun climb that stays in the shade till late afternoon.
content.protection: Pro to 3", mostly smaller.  Cold shuts at top
content.location: Lively up Yourself is located in the "Eastern Segment" of Spring Mountain.  About 15' to the right of the arete climb "Spring Fever" and the large chimney behind it.

content.description: Steep face climb 10 ft. right of Spring Fever, just past chimney containing large rotten logs.

Stem and chimney up the wide crack system, step right across the chimney to a ledge system then scamper up a beautiful exposed arete, moving left briefly two bolts from the top. Need a 60 m rope to lower from top anchors.
content.location: Starts in the offwidth crack 20 ft. right of Blister in the Sun.

content.description: Starts at anchor for The Final Shred. Continue straight up.

Face climb 10 ft right of Stemulation. Lower section climbs past 7 bolts to anchors and is considerably harder if you avoid the arete on the right side. Continue through roof above first belay past 3 more bolts to chains.
Left side of arete 10 ft. right of Nut Up.
Difficulty varies between 10a (right side start) and 10c (left side start).
content.location: Face climb right of beginners route.

content.description: Start near crack 10 ft. right of Blue-tailed Skink. Cross crack between 1st and 2nd bolts and climb face just left of crack to large ledge with Blue-Tailed Skink anchors. Scramble up more ledges, clipping two bolts, until large handholds allow an exciting move right onto a slabby face. Climb this fun face to a corner with large blocks below an overhang. A series of exciting "iron cross" moves left and out around the overhang establishes you on a final short face just below the anchors. This is a long, fun climb with lots of bolts. 20 to be exact.
content.protection: Use a 60 m rope and take 20 quick draws! Chains at the top.

content.description: When crack system widens and splits 20 ft. up, take the left fork. Climb past one bolt to a ledge and follow the crack system to the top. Five bolts can be clipped (some placed for adjacent routes) between the ledge and the top, but be sure to take supplemental pro.
content.location: Start at two-inch crack 15 ft. right of Ticked

content.description: This is a short route in the south talus field. Some fun climbing leads to a good rest and a really fun crux throw.
content.location: South talus field just right of geophysical.

content.description: Crack climb 10 ft. right of Marley's Route. The obvious initial jam or layback sequence is pretty fun.
content.protection: Gear to 3". Chains at the top.

content.description: Awesome stemming and jamming up steep corner. Ends after 60 ft. at chain anchors left of crack.
content.protection: Gear, TCU to protect crux sequence

content.description: Bolted slab just right of Aloha Direct (with which it shares an anchor).
Climbs right side of steep arete past big chimney 30' right of Doc Holiday.
Clip first two bolts of Freddy's Dead and head up and right on steep thin face. Can also be climbed by clipping first two bolts on Doc Holiday then branching off to the left.
Jam and lieback steep thin crack to the "Womb of Doom" below large chockstones. Stem out, around, and over chockstones to bouldery ledge with rap anchor belay.
Very short steep face. Stick clip first bolt. Crux is getting the 2nd clip. Arete on right is off-route.
content.location: First bolted route.

content.description: Just like Godzilla's foe by the same name, this beast has three "heads". Begin in the dihedral right of Summertime Arete. Stick clip first bolt and climb the face (5.10a) or use the crack (5.7). After the 6th or 7th bolt there are three ways to finish. For the middle or right head, down climb a bit and unclip the last bolt on the "torso" after you clip the first bolt on the "neck" to prevent rope drag. Left head (5.10b, 11 bolts): Continue straight up on a slab on the left side of the crack/chimney system and crimp up a steep rounded arete to a ledge with cold shuts. Middle head (5.9, 15 bolts): From friction slab above ledge, step right across a wide dirt-filled crack and climb a steep but juggy face to chain anchors at the top of the cliff. Right head: (5.9, 15 bolts) From ledge with chains for Summertime Arete step right across crack to steep knobby face. Climb straight up to chains at the top of the cliff.
Red arete just right of Dawg Daze.

A really fun but somewhat dirty crack that ascends the main wall. The crux was a really fun fist crack in a dihedral that turned OW on me, I believe that this is where it gets geophysical. the route then finishes up a dirty hand crack in a dihedral. Good stuff.
content.protection: Mixed. there are some bolts next to easily protectable cracks, I dunno I clipped them so I am not going to cry about it.
content.location: at the left side of the main wall or amphitheater.

content.description: Climbs slabby face to steep finish 20 ft. right of Blue Suede Shoes.
Slabby arete 20 ft. right of Hawaiian Slab.
This route is on top of the 'Ticked' and it is usually accessed by climbing up 'Chunky Monkey' and you can then climb from the large ledge.  Goes up a steep overhang, full sport.
Follows right side of steep arete around the corner from Chubby Hubby. Horizontal pockets lead to knobs and a small roof. Finish via crack on right = 11b, via face on left =12a.
This route climbs the face left of sphinx crack. It has some really nice big, powerful moves on good holds before reaching the flake. Crack climbers will find the crux easy ;)
content.location: this is the obvious, overhanging, right leaning undercling, just left of mojo and sphinx.

content.description: Wide crack right of Spider. Rarely climbed, somewhat dirty.
content.protection: Shares chain anchor with Moving to Manhatten.

content.description: Steep face right of By Hook or by Crook.

On outside face of butress 6 ft. right of M.T.P. Climb steep thin face past six clips to rap hangers on ledge (5.10d). Quit here or move left and continue past 6 more bolts to anchors near the top of the cliff (5.10b). 12 bolts, intermediate and top anchors.
This route climbs a steep face just left of large crack system that hosts The Last Dance.
Short slabby face a few feet right of Bat Crack.
Climbs a gentler section of the same slab as Mirage a' Trois starting about 8 feet farther right. Crux is getting to the first clip.
content.protection: 5 bolts to rap hangers. Stick-clip suggested.

content.description: Stem and jam the crack in the dihedral between Face the Facts and By Hook or by Crook. After 40 ft., traverse right to finish.
Steep face 10 ft. right of Iron Cross. The 5.11b grade applies only to a line straight up the bolts. Using the corner and crack system on the left lowers the grade to about 5.10c.
Crank through the devious overhang (crux) and continue up slab to short steep headwall.
content.protection: Stick clip first bolt. 9 bolts to rap hangers.
content.location: Start at short overhang at left side of first talus field.

content.description: Face climb on slab above large roof 15 ft right of By Hook or by Crook. Just left of Bat Crack. Above the third bolt it is possible to traverse left to double cold shut anchors for "unnamed" or to anchors for By Hook or by Crook. Exterminailer continues up and right above roof past 4 more clips (and moss) to rap hangers near the top.
Steep face with pockets behind the big dead tree right of Chopper. Clip the chains and come down or mantle over the lip to reach the anchors for Oot.
A fun little roof problem in the amphitheater. It takes an easy line up to a roof with good holds. I couldn't make it look pretty (just thug away)but it was still a fun climb.
content.location: This route is the obvious overhang in the area.

content.description: Climb crack in right-facing corner 10 ft. right of Phlogistomat.
content.protection: Gear to rap hangers 45 ft. up.

content.description: A good climb but not super memorable.
content.location: Just right of Twister.  A crack climb before a larger chimney and the detached buttress where Phish Food and Spring Fever are located.

content.description: Takes left side of overhanging arete to slab 4 ft. right of Dog Show.

Start up Mt. Berry and cut left and follow bolts on steep face climbing.  Has good crimps & ledges and exposed boulder problem at chains. Grade is given to stay on face entire way up.  If you use crack on left, stem, etc. then it is 5.11.
Face between Longtime Coming and Hospital Corner. This one may seem more like a 12 until you figure out the sequence!

This is a powerful, but short line that gave me a full value pump. Mostly long reaches on good in-cut pockets up some overhanging terrain. I thought that the technical crux was the first move onto the face, but when going for the red-point it was definitely holding on for the ride. A really good route requiring some technique and also some power.  

  On a side note I am pretty sure some chipping was done on this route.
content.protection: 5 or 6 clips and two rap bolts for an anchor. Given the popularity of this route it is a candidate for lower-offs.
content.location: In what I believe to be the "forest area." This is one of the first routes you come to where the trail meets the cliffs. It shares a start with "Skinny Hippie" and can be discerned from the other routes by the obvious overhanging finish.

content.description: Ascend steep face on outside of buttress right of Freddy's Dead to ledge below blunt arete. Climb blunt arete via devious balance and friction to double cold shuts at ledge with dead trees. End here or continue up knobby face past 5 more bolts to top of pinnacle ("Extended Holiday"). Need 60 meter rope to toprope from highest anchors. Unclip from cold shut anchor before continuing to top to lessen rope drag.
content.protection: 15 bolts to cold shuts midway or chains at top.

content.description: First pitch - Climb the crack and face to the belay for Welcome to Spring Mountain.    Second pitch - Climb the steep off-width to the top of the cliff.
content.protection: Standard rack, a 4.5" camming device is useful for the off-width
content.location: The crack just to the right of Welcome to Spring Mountain.

content.description: Steep thin crack right of Stemulation. Shares double cold shut anchor with Stemulation.

Climb a ledgy face to a steep pull past a giant chockstone. Stem and/or chimney up a corner with two wide cracks clipping bolts on the face to the left. Make a delicate traverse move onto the face to the left of the corner and up to a good ledge. Finish with an airy step out to the right to reach the anchors.
content.location: This is the middle route at the head of the steep eroding slope.

content.description: This fun little crack climbs a left facing dihedral to a small roof. Pull the roof and get established on a ledge, then climb a really nice hand crack in a pod to another small roof. Step right at this roof and tackle another nice but short crack to reach the chains. The crux was the first roof although the final crack is not a gimme either.
content.location: The second crack to the right of Lorraine.

content.description: Climb the crack just right of Triple Threat. Ends on ledge with double cold shuts.
Climb face 5 ft. right of Triple Threat. Crux at third bolt.

First crack right of Betaflash. Jam the delightful handcrack, surmount the large flake (it's solid), and continue past some quick-clip anchors to a delightful bolt-protected chimney. Feel free to bail out at the first anchors if you are intimidated by the chimney.

Stem up the arete/dihedral 10 ' right of Something Else. After 45 ft. and 6 bolts (5.7), stop at chains on a big ledge or continue straight up over big blocks past two more bolts to a fun crack system in a dihedral (gear, 1-4"). Ends at chains just below the top.

This route, the longest at Spring Mountain, starts behind a tree 15 ft. right of Face Lift. Traverse up and left on ramp-like ledges to a steep slot. Stem through the slot and up a ledgy dihedral. Stop at chains at a big ledge above the dihedral or work left above the Face Lift anchors and climb the outside of a blocky pillar past 6 more bolts to the top of the cliff.
content.protection: Do not lower anyone from the top anchors unless you have a 60 meter rope! 15 bolts to chains.

content.description: Crack in corner right of Eaten Alive. Dirty. Finishes at Eaten Alive anchors.

A nice long route that starts in the crack left of Chubby Hubby.  Wide variety of styles.  There are anchors at the top of the first block but with a 60m rope you can continue up and right for one long pitch.  Some loose blocks at the top below the anchors but there are plenty of options on the face to the right.
content.location: In the "central segment" just left of Chubby Hubby

content.description: Great climbing up a steep face and arete.  Difficulty ticks up as you go up.
content.location: In the "central segment."  Prominent arete

climbs.name: Chopper
climbs.fa: Bob Branscomb, Kristi Stouffer, Jack Kay and Linda Hall. 80's

content.description: Dihedral with crack right of Mr. Flexible. Shares chains with Mr. Flexible.
content.protection: Gear to shared anchor with Mr. Flexible

content.description: Features 3 10d cruxes. Seldom climbed, upper part is dirty.
content.location: Face climb 5 ft. right of Lorraine

content.description: Wide crack leading to flaring slot with large chockstone just right of unnamed 12b.
content.protection: Bring big pro! There are belay chains on the ledge at the top of the crack

content.description: Runout mossy and slabby face right of Feat Petite
Gently overhanging face right of Face the Crook.
Climbs left side of blunt arete at entrance to first talus field.
Short face climb 10 ft. right of Special Delivery. Steep climbing on big holds leads to thin crux on slabbier section above.
Starts at large flake near big ponderosa pine. Takes line just to the right of Wanderer.
Climb the crack between Johnny's Got a Gun and Betaflash. Ends at chains for Betaflash.
content.protection: Gear to shared anchor with Betaflash.

content.description: Climb through the big scary, detached block (it's solid) and move out onto the finger crack in the face right of Freddy's Dead.
content.protection: gear to anchor shared with Freddy's Dead

content.description: Steep arete with lime green lichen near center of second talus field. Crux is on a blank slab 2 bolts below the anchors.
Some fun moves up to a gently, overhanging black streak. bear down an push through this to reach the chains.
content.location: This is the obvious overhanging black streak to the left of the pod of god and rally racer.

content.description: Climbs the arete just right of Blockhead. Traverse in from boulders on the right to clip the first bolt. Start from the traverse or scramble back down and start at the base of the cliff to add more fun climbing.
Low angle slab.It is easy to set a top-rope by walking around to the left. Great climb for kids or anyone getting their first taste of outdoor climbing.
content.location: Around the corner to the right of Gome Boy.

climbs.name: Bat Crack
climbs.fa: Bob Branscomb, Kristi Stouffer, Jack Kay and Linda Hall.

content.description:
A great lead for a beginning tradster. This is a really good route for the grade. It climbs large dihedral with a perfect hand and finger crack up to two bolts on the right face of the dihedral. I have been told that one can exit left out the roof but I am pretty sure this is rarely done. 

  FA around 1984 by Bob Branscomb, Kristi Stouffer, Jack Kay and Linda Hall.
content.protection: standard rack and two extra runners for the bolted anchor.
content.location: One of the first routes you come to on the approach. This crack is in an obvious large dihedral with a huge featureless roof.

content.description: A tricky sequence a couple moves up will make you wish you placed a couple good pieces right off the ground, well-named route as the locks are a bit "strenuous".
content.location: obvious overhanging finger crack that splits a blank face near the middle of the wall, the base is usually obscured by brush, chain anchors

content.description: Bolted face climb 4 ft. right of Mojo Risin'.

A surprising number of good routes spring out of the timber at this cragging area in NE Oregon.  There is a nice variety of sport and trad climbs anywhere from 5.4 to 5.13 on fairly solid andesite.  Most of the climbs are about a half pitch in length but there are a few multi-pitch routes that top out.   

  The crag is nestled in the Blue Mountains and has an excellent vista of the nearby mountains including Mount Emily that overlooks the nearby Grande Ronde Valley.  Large talus fields line the base of the crag and create an area for lazy belayers and bystanders to soak in the sun.  The relatively high elevation and ability to find shady areas makes this an ideal summer crag for those hanging out in Eastern Oregon.  Most people wait till the snow melts (usually April) to venture up the gravel roads.   

  These days the crag gets fairly crowded on the weekends with an influx of climbers from Walla Walla and Portland but usually climbers can still get a secluded feel by skipping the first talus field.
